definitions: remaining after the greater part or quantity has been removed, used, or dealt with
relating to or denoting a quantity or substance left over as residue
examples: There was residual anger in her voice
The residual effects of the medication lasted for hours
Scientists analyzed the residual material in the flask
The residual deposits formed a thin layer

definitions: able to withstand or recover quickly from difficult conditions or setbacks
physically flexible and strong enough to spring back into shape after being bent or stretched
examples: Children are remarkably resilient after emotional trauma
The resilient economy bounced back from recession
The resilient rubber material absorbed the impact
This resilient fabric keeps its shape after washing

definitions: containing resin or having the sticky, glossy qualities of plant resin
examples: The resinous pine branches smelled strongly in summer
A resinous coating protected the wooden surface

definitions: offering resistance to something or someone that tries to affect or influence
not harmed or affected by something harmful, especially disease or treatment
examples: The material is resistant to water damage
She remained resistant to their persuasion attempts
These bacteria are resistant to antibiotics
The resistant strain of wheat survived the drought

definitions: offering resistance to the flow of electric current in a circuit
having the property of resisting motion, influence, or change
examples: The resistive heating element warmed the room
Engineers calculated the resistive load on circuit
The resistive force slowed the object's movement
His resistive attitude made cooperation difficult

definitions: admirably purposeful, determined, and unwavering in purpose or belief
examples: She remained resolute despite facing criticism
His resolute determination helped him succeed

definitions: firmly determined to do something with clear purpose
having been settled, solved, or dealt with successfully
examples: She was resolved to finish her degree
The resolved expression on his face showed determination
The resolved dispute allowed them to move forward
All resolved issues were removed from the agenda

definitions: producing a deep, full, reverberating sound that continues to vibrate
having the power to evoke enduring images, memories, or strong emotions
examples: His resonant voice filled the concert hall
The resonant tones of the bell echoed
The speech contained resonant themes of justice
Her resonant words stayed with the audience

definitions: producing or filled with a deep, full, reverberating sound
having a strong, lasting emotional or intellectual effect on someone
examples: The resonating strings created beautiful harmonics
A resonating chamber amplified the sound
Her resonating message inspired the entire team
The resonating impact of the film lasted days

definitions: producing a loud, deep, or reverberating sound that echoes
unmistakably great or complete in degree, used for emphasis
examples: A resounding crash came from the kitchen
The resounding applause lasted several minutes
The team won a resounding victory
Her resounding success surprised even supporters

definitions: having the ability to find quick and clever ways to overcome difficulties
examples: The resourceful student solved problems creatively
A resourceful manager makes the most of limited budgets

definitions: regarded by society as being good, proper, or correct in behavior
of a size, amount, or quality that is satisfactory or reasonably good
examples: They lived in a respectable neighborhood
His respectable reputation helped his career
She earned a respectable salary for her work
A respectable crowd attended the opening night

definitions: admired and held in high esteem due to abilities, qualities, or achievements
examples: The respected professor received many awards
She became a respected leader in her field

definitions: feeling or showing deference and respect for others' rights and feelings
examples: Students maintained respectful silence during ceremony
His respectful manner impressed the elders

definitions: belonging or relating separately to each of two or more people or things
examples: The students returned to their respective classrooms
They went their respective ways after graduation

definitions: relating to or affecting respiration or the organs of respiration
examples: The patient developed respiratory problems after surgery
Doctors monitored her respiratory rate carefully

definitions: attractive and impressive through being richly colorful or sumptuous in appearance
examples: The resplendent peacock displayed its feathers
She looked resplendent in her wedding gown

definitions: reacting quickly and positively to suggestions, changes, or influences
answering or replying readily to questions, requests, or communications
examples: The responsive design adapted to screen sizes
Markets are responsive to consumer demands
The responsive customer service solved issues quickly
He was always responsive to emails

definitions: having had sufficient rest to feel refreshed and restored in energy
examples: She felt rested after the long weekend
The rested athletes performed at their best

definitions: having a quiet and soothing quality that promotes rest or relaxation
examples: The restful music helped her fall asleep
They enjoyed a restful vacation by the lake

definitions: unable to keep still or silent, typically because of impatience or boredom
stubbornly refusing to be controlled or refusing to move forward
examples: The restive audience began talking during delays
Children grew restive during the long ceremony
The restive horse refused to enter the trailer
Workers became restive under strict management

definitions: unable to rest or relax due to anxiety, boredom, or excitement
examples: She spent a restless night worrying about exams
The restless child couldn't sit still

definitions: having the ability to restore health, strength, or well-being to someone
examples: The restorative powers of sleep helped recovery
A restorative yoga class relaxed tense muscles

definitions: characterized by being held back from action or expression
characterized by reserve or moderation, avoiding excess or extremes
examples: His restrained anger showed only in clenched fists
The restrained prisoner couldn't move freely
The restrained color palette created elegant rooms
Her restrained response avoided escalating conflict

definitions: limited in access to certain people or for certain purposes only
limited or confined in extent, number, or scope of action
examples: The restricted area required security clearance
Access to restricted documents needed approval
Their restricted budget limited travel options
The restricted diet excluded many foods

definitions: putting limitations or restrictions on someone's actions or movements
examples: The restricting regulations limited business growth
Her restricting clothing made movement difficult

definitions: imposing restrictions or limitations on someone's activities or freedom
examples: The restrictive dress code banned casual wear
Restrictive laws limited freedom of speech

definitions: occurring or produced as a result or consequence of something
examples: The resultant damage from flooding was extensive
Her resultant wealth came from wise investments

definitions: increasing or reviving after a period of little activity or decline
examples: The resurgent economy showed strong growth
A resurgent interest in vinyl records emerged

definitions: restored to consciousness or life after apparent death or unconsciousness
examples: The resuscitated patient slowly regained awareness
Paramedics successfully resuscitated the drowning victim

definitions: continued to have something in one's possession or use
examples: The retained earnings funded company expansion
She retained control of the family business

definitions: characterized by or done as retaliation for harm or wrong suffered
examples: The retaliatory strikes escalated the conflict
They feared retaliatory action from competitors

definitions: not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily, tending toward silence
examples: He remained reticent about his personal life
The reticent witness needed encouragement to testify

definitions: relating to or affecting the retina of the eye
examples: The retinal scan provided security access
Doctors detected retinal damage during examination

definitions: shy and fond of being on one's own, avoiding social situations
leaving one's job and ceasing to work, typically due to age
examples: Her retiring nature made public speaking difficult
The retiring personality preferred working alone
The retiring CEO received a gold watch
Many retiring employees attended the farewell party

definitions: able to be drawn back or withdrawn into a larger part
examples: The retractable roof opened for sunny days
A retractable leash gave the dog more freedom

definitions: drawn back or in from an extended position
formally withdrawn or taken back, as a statement or accusation
examples: The retracted claws remained hidden in fur
The retracted landing gear allowed smooth flight
The retracted statement cleared his reputation
She retracted her earlier accusations publicly

definitions: imitating a style, fashion, or design from the recent past
examples: The retro diner featured 1950s decor
She wore retro clothing to the theme party

definitions: taking effect from a date in the past, especially applying to past events
examples: The retroactive pay increase covered three months
New retroactive laws raised constitutional concerns

definitions: directed or moving backward from usual direction
reverting to an earlier and inferior condition, showing deterioration
examples: The planet's retrograde motion puzzled ancient astronomers
Retrograde amnesia erased recent memories
His retrograde views belonged to past centuries
The policy represented retrograde thinking on rights

definitions: looking back on or dealing with past events or situations
applying to or influencing things done in the past
examples: The retrospective analysis revealed missed opportunities
A retrospective exhibition showcased her life's work
The retrospective tax changes affected previous years
Retrospective legislation rarely gains approval

definitions: coming or going back to a place or person after absence
examples: The returning students enrolled for fall semester
Returning customers received special discounts

definitions: able to be used again after initial use, typically after cleaning
examples: Reusable containers reduced plastic waste significantly
The reusable rocket lowered launch costs

definitions: making previously unknown or secret information known to others
allowing more than usual to be seen, especially of the body
examples: His revealing comments exposed the truth
The revealing investigation uncovered fraud
She changed out of the revealing dress
The revealing outfit wasn't appropriate for work

definitions: revealing something hitherto unknown, especially something striking or profound
examples: The revelatory document changed historical understanding
Her revelatory performance stunned the critics

definitions: regarded with deep respect and admiration, often approaching veneration
examples: The revered leader inspired generations of followers
Ancient revered texts guided their beliefs

definitions: deserving or inspiring deep respect and reverence
used as a title for members of the clergy
examples: The reverend gentleman commanded respect
His reverend bearing impressed the congregation
The Reverend Smith delivered Sunday's sermon
Several reverend fathers attended the conference

definitions: feeling or showing deep and solemn respect, often religious
examples: The reverent crowd bowed their heads in prayer
She maintained reverent silence in the temple

definitions: turned around to face or move in the opposite direction
changed to the opposite or contrary of what it was
examples: The reversed image appeared in the mirror
Cars followed the reversed traffic pattern
Their reversed decision surprised everyone involved
The reversed roles challenged traditional expectations

definitions: able to be turned the other way around or inside out
able to be worn or used with either side as the outer surface
examples: The reversible chemical reaction reached equilibrium
This reversible process could be undone
Her reversible jacket offered two color options
The reversible belt matched different outfits
